results.title: Atoms and starlight
results.creator_credit: Coastal Community Colleges and David P. Stone
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
The use of spectroscopy and spectrum analysis have been vital when astronomers study the stars. The continous, emission and dark-line spectra have enabled scientists to determine the composition of stars and to modify the original classification of stars. Atoms of elements have their own unique “fingerprint’ spectrum which can be determined by studying the behaviour of photons and electrons. With the advances in fibre optics, spectographs can now measure many stars instead on one, and thus determine the nature of a group of celestial bodies within a galaxy.

results.title: Atoms and molecules
results.brief_description: Sir Lawrence Bragg describes and illustrates the structure of atoms and molecules, demonstrates their size and the progressive development of microscopic instruments and techniques, and performs experiments showing the wetting of oil molecules and the Brownian movement. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Atomisation
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Bill Mason
results.brief_description: Atomisation is defined as the breaking up of liquids into minute drops for efficient burning or economical spreading. Different methods of atomising liquids; scent spray; centrifugal spinning cup plus air blast; pressure jet. Slowed movement illustrations (150X) show how atomisation occurs. Main uses: agricultural and for burning liquid fuel. Various methods of qualitative and quantitative evaluation of spray patterns. Testing jet aircraft atomizers.

results.title: Atomic structure and correlations within the Periodic Table
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Andrew Patterson, Jr and David G. Anderson
results.brief_description: The first episode of this film looks at atomic structure and the Periodic Table, and the second episoe looks at correlations with the Periodic Table. Using a blackboard size Periodic Table from which individual elements can be removed or placed at will, this film illustrates a method of using the Periodic system to determine the electronic structure of atoms. Suitable for Upper-Secondary students.

results.title: Atomic juggernaut
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Walford Hewitson, Tom Daly and Eugene Boyko
results.brief_description: In India they call it Anushkati - the atomic juggernaut - a modern miracle brought from Canada to light an entire region. This film shows the strange procession made by the calandria, the heart of the nuclear reactor, hauled by huge diesel tractors from the seaport in India to the proposed site of the reactor, along a roadway specially prepared beforehand. Everywhere the juggernaut passed, ancient life stopped for a moment to witness the arrival of this new deity.

results.title: Atomic footprints
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr Productions and Pip Starr
results.brief_description:
The debate surrounding the production of nuclear energy goes back to the bombing of Hiroshima at the end of World War II. Since then, the proliferation of nuclear energy and weapons has been used as a deterrant, a bolstering of military power and, in the early 2000’s, as a solution to combat global warming.

With the Prime Minister John Howard’s comments regarding not ruling out atomic power stations, this documentary considers the implications to the environment, the people living on the land, our health and our future.

results.title: Atomic energy explained
results.creator_credit: Film Producers Guild and British Information Services
results.brief_description: A practical outline of atomic energy and its peaceful applications. Studies the structure of atomic particles and shows how energy can be released from them to produce atomic power. Also illustrates how radio-isotopes are being put to valuable use in modern industry and medicine. No other credits available.

results.title: Atomic achievement
results.creator_credit: Rayant Pictures, Anthony Gilkison and John Reeve
results.brief_description: An account of Britain’s vast nuclear power program for a new industrial era, and of progress to date. Operational centres visited by the film include Calder Hall, the first full-scale nuclear power station; the great atomic research centre at Harwell; the atomic factories at Springfields, Capenhurst and Windscale; and the “fast breeder-reactor” under construction at Dounreay. Animated diagrams explain the working of a nuclear reactor.
